title: Snake Bite
description: A snake bite occurs when a snakeâ€™s fangs puncture the skin, releasing venom into the bloodstream if the snake is venomous. Snake bites can cause serious injuries or death if not treated promptly.

sections.heading: Symptoms of a Snake Bite
sections.content: Two puncture wounds usually from fangs, pain or swelling at the bite site, redness or bruising around the bite, nausea or vomiting, difficulty breathing, dizziness or fainting, blurred vision, rapid heart rate or low blood pressure, and fever or chills if infection occurs.

sections.heading: Steps for Snake Bite First Aid
sections.content:
1) Stay calm and keep the victim calm to prevent venom spread.
2) Call emergency services immediately and provide location and snake description if possible.
3) Keep the victim still and position the bitten limb below heart level.
4) Apply a loose bandage above the bite to slow venom spread without cutting off circulation.
5) Avoid sucking out venom, applying ice or tourniquets, catching or killing the snake, and giving alcohol or stimulants.
6) Monitor victim's condition and keep them as still as possible.

sections.heading: What to Do While Waiting for Help
sections.content:
Keep the wound clean by gently washing with soap and water without scrubbing.
Mark the time the bite occurred to inform medical staff.

sections.heading: When to Seek Emergency Medical Care
sections.content:
Seek immediate medical attention if the snake is venomous or unknown.
If symptoms like difficulty breathing, blurred vision, or intense swelling occur.
Get to the nearest healthcare facility promptly if help is delayed.

sections.heading: Treatment at the Hospital
sections.content:
Administration of antivenom to neutralize venom.
Wound cleaning and infection monitoring.
Supportive care including pain management, fluids, and breathing support.
Observation for several hours for complications.

sections.heading: Precautions to Prevent Snake Bites
sections.content:
Wear protective clothing such as boots and long pants in snake-prone areas.
Be cautious around rocks, logs, and tall grass where snakes hide.
Do not disturb snakes; back away slowly if encountered.
Teach children to avoid playing with snakes or unknown animals.
